items.title: Num_format overrides formula in add_table
items.body:
Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to create a spreadsheet where a column has a formula definition and currency formatting but the formula appears to be overridden (table 1). When the formatting is removed, the formula reappears (table 2)

Interestingly, if a default value is added in one row, the formula persists for that row and excel shows an "Inconsistent Calculated Column Formula" error for that cell (table 3).

I am using Python version 3.7.6 and XlsxWriter 1.3.2 and Excel version 260 (Version 2002 Build 12527.20880).

Here is some code that demonstrates the problem:

```python
import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook(r'E:/test.xlsx')
worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet()
currency = workbook.add_format({'num_format':'_-$* #,##0.00_-;-$* #,##0.00_-;_-$* "-"??_-;_-@_-'})
# Table 1
worksheet.add_table('A1:C3', {'data': [[1,2,None], [1,2,None]],
                              'columns': [{'header': 'A'},
                                          {'header': 'B'},
                                          {'header': 'C', 'formula':'[@A]*[@B]', 'format':currency}
                                          ]})
# Table 2
worksheet.add_table('A5:C7', {'data': [[1,2,None], [1,2,5]],
                              'columns': [{'header': 'A'},
                                          {'header': 'B'},
                                          {'header': 'C', 'formula':'[@A]*[@B]'}
                                          ]})
# Table 1
worksheet.add_table('A9:C11', {'data': [[1,2,None], [1,2,5]],
                              'columns': [{'header': 'A'},
                                          {'header': 'B'},
                                          {'header': 'C', 'formula':'[@A]*[@B]', 'format':currency}
                                          ]})
workbook.close()
```

items.title: "We found a problem with some content..." when creating spreadsheet.
items.body:
"We found a problem with some content..." when opening the spreadsheet.

Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to create a spreadsheet with a table but when opening the created spreadsheet in Excel it displays a "we found a problem with some content..." prompt. Excel can recover the document but this isn't ideal.

I am using Python version 3.7.6 and XlsxWriter 1.3.2 and Excel version 260 (Version 2002 Build 12527.20880).

Here is some code that demonstrates the problem:

```python

import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook(r'E:/test.xlsx')
worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet()
worksheet.add_table('B3:D5',{'autofilter':1})
worksheet.write('B3','column 1')
worksheet.write('C3','column 2')
worksheet.write('D3','column 3')
worksheet.write('B4',1)
worksheet.write('C4','a')
worksheet.write('D4','c')
worksheet.write('B5',2)

workbook.close()
```

The Excel repairs are:

items.title: cell width bug
items.body:
Tested on latest (1.3.1) version.

Below code will not apply cell width changes to columns A:AA, it will only apply cell width changes to A and D.
The bug appears to be if you set a global cell change range and then apply another change on the first cell in the global range, in this case A.
Workarounds are changing the global range to remove the singular change, B:AA, or removing the custom cell change on column A.


`import xlsxwriter`

`workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('xlsx_bug.xlsx')`

`worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet()`

`#global cell changes`
`worksheet.set_column('A:AA', 20)`

`#individual cell changes`
`worksheet.set_column('A:A', 25)`
`worksheet.set_column('D:D', 50)`

`workbook.close()`

items.title: Formula misinterpreted by Excel, but OK in LibreOffice Calc
items.body:
Hi,

In generated file and LibreOffice Calc formula appear as `=SUMPRODUCT(C1:C2,TRANSPOSE(A1:B1))`. In Excel as `=SUMPRODUCT(C1:C2,TRANSPOSE(@A1:B1))` and value as `#VALUE!`

I am using Python version 2.7.12 and XlsxWriter 1.2.8 and Microsoft 365 Excel and LibreOffice Calc 6.0.

Here is some code that demonstrates the problem:

```python
import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('test.xlsx')

cell_format = workbook.add_format({ 'align': 'left' })
cell_format.set_bg_color('#FFFFFF')
cell_format.set_border(style=1)

worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet('Test')
worksheet.write_number(0, 0, 1, cell_format)
worksheet.write_number(0, 1, 2, cell_format)
worksheet.write_number(0, 2, 5, cell_format)
worksheet.write_number(1, 0, 3, cell_format)
worksheet.write_number(1, 1, 4, cell_format)
worksheet.write_number(1, 2, 6, cell_format)

values = [17, 39]

for i in range(2):
    formula = '=SUMPRODUCT({0}:{1},TRANSPOSE({2}:{3}))'.format(
        xlsxwriter.utility.xl_rowcol_to_cell(0, 2),
        xlsxwriter.utility.xl_rowcol_to_cell(1, 2),
        xlsxwriter.utility.xl_rowcol_to_cell(i, 0),
        xlsxwriter.utility.xl_rowcol_to_cell(i, 1))
    worksheet.write_formula(i, 3, formula, cell_format, values[i])

workbook.close()
```

items.title: Issue with cell range not being set correctly with write_array_formula()
items.body:
Issue reported on [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/q/63216996/10238).

The following doesn't write the array formula in cell B1 of Sheet2. This is due to a bug in the range calculation. The bug is hidden in Sheet1 due to other cells setting the range.

```python

import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('test.xlsx')

sheet1 = workbook.add_worksheet('Sheet1')
sheet2 = workbook.add_worksheet('Sheet2')

sheet1.write('A1', 'Foo')
sheet1.write('A2', 'Bar')

sheet1.write_array_formula('B1:B2', '{=Sheet1!$A$1:$A$2}')
sheet2.write_array_formula('B1:B2', '{=Sheet1!$A$1:$A$2}')

workbook.close()
```

items.title: References to other cells
items.body:
I am using Python 3.8.5 (Mac OS) and open the resulting `xlsx` files with `LibreOffice 6.4.5.2` and `Apple Numbers 10.1 (6913)` (sorry, I have no MS Excel installed).

I am trying to add formulas that refer to other cells (both cross-sheet and within the same sheet), but they do not work. Here is some code that demonstrates the problem:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

# % locale
# LANG="ru_RU.UTF-8"
# LC_COLLATE="ru_RU.UTF-8"
# LC_CTYPE="ru_RU.UTF-8"
# LC_MESSAGES="ru_RU.UTF-8"
# LC_MONETARY="ru_RU.UTF-8"
# LC_NUMERIC="ru_RU.UTF-8"
# LC_TIME="ru_RU.UTF-8"
# LC_ALL=

# pip install XlsxWriter==1.2.9
import xlsxwriter

wb = xlsxwriter.Workbook('xlsx_bug.xlsx')
sheet1 = wb.add_worksheet("Sheet 1")
sheet2 = wb.add_worksheet("Sheet 2")

sheet2.write(0, 0, 'Cell 2')
sheet1.write_formula(0, 0, "='Sheet 2'.A1")
sheet1.write_formula(1, 0, "='Sheet 2'!A1")
wb.close()
```

If I higlight the `A1` or `A2` cell on `Sheet 1` and press `F4` (it changes a cell reference from absolute to relative), both formulas start to work.

The same could be done on the markup level by changing the following syntax:

`<c r="A2"><f>'Sheet 2'!A1</f><v>0</v></c>`

to this one:

`<c r="A2"><f>'Sheet 2'!A1</f></c>`

And this is how the cell looks like when saved by LibreOffice:

`<c r="A2" s="0" t="str"><f aca="false">'Sheet 2'!A1</f><v>Cell 2</v></c>`

## Feature requests

Add `Feature request:` conditional formatting with custom icons.

Hi, 
It would be great to have a small enrichment on the conditional formatting features: the possibility to choose specific icons, when we are dealing with type = Icon set. 

My proposal would be to add another option of icon_style: custom. 
This would actually reflect the existing functionality of excel (example in the screenshot here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/0b5uekizb5z7259/image.png?dl=0)

here an example of how the configuration could looks like

```python
worksheet.conditional_format(
    'A1:D1',
    {'type': 'icon_set',
     'icon_style': '**custom**,
     'icons': [{'criteria': '>=', 'type': 'number','value': 90, **'icon':'Icon1'**},
               {'criteria': '<',  'type': 'percentile','value': 50,**'icon':'Icon2'**},
               {'criteria': '<=', 'type': 'percent','value': 25,**'icon':'Icon3'**}]}
)
```

I hope is clear..

I check both documentation and actual code and I did not find this possibility, it would be great to have it to enable more complex logics while dealing with conditional formatting. 

I am not using any workaround, if you have anything to suggest feel free :)

PS: thanks a lot you your work, is a really good library!

items.title: xlsx Table with totals_row not Working in LibreOffice
items.body:
Creating an xlsx sheet with a table including a totals row gives an error in LibreOffice.

Details: Using XlsxWriter (version 0.9.6 and 1.2.9) and configuring a table
including a "totals_row" like this:

 ```
  options = {
     'columns': [
        {'header': 'SSt',
	     'total_function': 'sum'},
         ...
         ],
     'totals_row': True,
     }
  worksheet.add_table(first_row, first_col, last_row, last_col, options)
```
then we get a warning in LibreOffice (version 6.2 and 6.3):
```
  Automatic update of external links has been disabled. [Enable Content]
```
And clicking on "Enable Content" gives:
```
  The following external file couldn not be loaded. Data linked from
  this file did not get updated.

  file:///tmp/mozilla_wlang0/SSt
```
See this screenshot for an example:

![libreoffice-tables2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22004097/84591785-7b1fa480-ae41-11ea-8cf9-468ff3b396c8.png)

Loading the same sheet in Excel works perfectly fine. Storing it
(without changes) again to disk, shows the following difference:

sheet1.xml (created by XlsxWriter):
```
  SUBTOTAL(109,[SSt])
```
sheet1.xml (created by XlsxWriter, then read and written by Excel 2016):
```
  SUBTOTAL(109,Table1[SSt])
               ^^^^^^
```
Where "Table1" is the (default) table name.

So it seems, that Column notation "[COLNAME]" in LibreOffice needs the
table name in front: "TABNAME[COLNAME]". I do not know, if this is a
weakness in LibreOffice, or if Excel is just more tolerant. But if you
enter "SUBTOTAL(109,[SSt])" in Excel, it stores
"SUBTOTAL(109,Table1[SSt])" in the "sheet1.xml" part of the xlsx file.

So i think it would be better to write the table name into the
xlsx/xl/worksheets/sheet1.xml file (just like Excel does it).

items.title: Code Improve - Set Align
items.body:

```python
import xlsxwriter
```

items.title: Feature request: please add support for histogram chart type
items.body:
I believe Excel 2016 and newer adds support for the histogram chart type.  Please consider adding support for this chart type to XlsxWriter.  It will eliminate the need to generate the bin and count data for a data set.

Currently, the user must:
1. use numpy or matplotlib to determine the histogram bins and counts
2. write the bin and count data to the excel spreadsheet

Feature request: Worksheet method for formatting a range
items.body:
This is motivated by the weirdness that is Excel's "center across selection". After playing around with Excel for a bit, I now understand how this works. And it makes complete sense that it is achieved in XlsxWriter the way it is. However, I think it would be nice to have an additional worksheet method which makes it easier. I was thinking `format_range`, which would be somewhat like `merge_range` except that it doesn't actually merge the cells in the range. For example: ```python with xlsxwriter.Workbook('format_range_test.xlsx') as wb: style = wb.add_format({'align': 'center_across', 'border': 1}) ws = wb.add_worksheet() ws.format_range('B3:G4', 'Text in B3, centered across B through G', style) ``` The above would produce ![2020-04-07b (xlsxwriter image 1 - cropped)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4826859/78724606-d2fad600-78fb-11ea-913c-08b3a0f877a1.png) I was originally thinking of a more focused method, like `center_across` or `center_across_range`, but then got bogged down trying to figure out things like how to ensure that the format includes `center_across` alignment, whether to allow the method to accept multiple rows, etc. Just splatting a format over a range seems more straightforward. Even if `format_range` is a nonstarter, I think it's worth tweaking the documentation to give a little more of a hint at how this alignment works. Right now it says
Only one cell should contain the text, the other cells should be blank:
I think it would be better as
The text to be centered must be in the leftmost cell. The centered region extends to the right until a cell is encountered which either doesn't have center_across alignment or isn't blank.
Something like that, anyway.

items.title: Question: When did "Number Format Categories" get added?
items.body:
Sorry, this is just a frivolous question, but I am terribly curious. I am talking about the *feature* that a number format specified as a string (rather than as an index) registers with Excel as though the index had been used.

This behavior is *described* in the docs apparently starting in 1.2.7. At least, that's when the changelog mentions that the "Number Format Categories" section was added to the docs.

I am quite confident this behavior didn't always used to be there, because I had specifically converted some of my code to use number format indices rather than strings so that the proper category would be preselected in the Excel GUI upon opening.

I have basically no Git or GitHub skills, so I haven't been able to determine when this feature was added. I would guess that it coincided with the addition of the docs describing it. (For that matter, I can't even find a commit containing the relevant doc update.)

Oh, I should mention that this is a welcome feature. The format strings are obviously much more self-documenting than the indices, and I am looking forward to not using the indices anymore.

items.title: can't combine sheet.right_to_left() with and set_column with justify-center?
items.body:
Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to write RTL data. I want the worksheet to be right to left aligned, but the contents of each cell to be horizontally and vertically justified to the middle/center.

When I remove `sheet.right_to_left()` then the vertical and horizontal alignment work perfectly, however when I add it either before or after I'm using `set_column()`, all contents are justified to the right.

I am using Python version 3.8.1 and XlsxWriter 1.2.8 and Pages.

Here is some code that demonstrates the problem:

```python
import pandas as pd

top_movers_dict = {'שם יישוב': {350: 'מלכיאור לוי', 1207: 'שמואל}, 'top_movers': {350: -0.03, 1207: -0.011}, '23_scoring_pct': {350: 0.563, 1207: 0.729}, '22_scoring_pct': {350: 0.593, 1207: 0.74}, 'זבז_23': {350: 12693, 1207: 22565}}

top_movers = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(top_movers_dict)

# Create a Pandas Excel writer using XlsxWriter as the engine.
writer = pd.ExcelWriter("pandas_simple.xlsx", engine="xlsxwriter")
workbook = writer.book
cell_format = workbook.add_format({"valign": "vcenter", "align": "center"})

# Convert the dataframe to an XlsxWriter Excel object.
top_movers.to_excel(writer, sheet_name="Sheet1", index=False)
worksheet = writer.sheets["Sheet1"]  # pull worksheet object
worksheet.right_to_left()

for idx, col in enumerate(top_movers):  # loop through all columns
    series = top_movers[col]
    max_len = (
        max(
            (
                series.astype(str).map(len).max(),  # len of largest item
                len(str(series.name)),  # len of column name/header
            )
        )
        + 1
    )  # adding a little extra space
    worksheet.set_column(idx, idx, max_len, cell_format)  # set column width
# Close the Pandas Excel writer and output the Excel file.
writer.save()

```

items.title: Feature request : Add option to sanitize data filled in the worksheet
items.body:
Hi
In my company we use XlsxWriter to generate Excel files from data entered by users.

We had a secure audit and the people who made the audit found a vulnerability. In fact a user could write a formula in a form in the website to redirect some other user to a bad website.

For example if a user entered -cmd|’ /C start microsoft-edge:https://haveibeenpwned.com/'!’ the other user who download the file would be redirected to the website

I would like to make a pull request to allow developers to clean data easily.

The function would like to use to clean data is : the function proposed here : https://github.com/raphaelm/defusedcsv/blob/master/defusedcsv/csv.py#L15

I have 2 possibilities to make it simple to the developer to do that : 

1) The first possibility is to allow user to give an option to sanitize all the data he will write in the constructor of the object Workbook (what will give the option to the object Worksheet).
By default this option would be False so it will not cause any breaking change

2) The second possibility is allow the user to give `sanitize_data` as kwargs in the `write` function. In this case, the developer will be allowed to choose in which cell he want to sanitize data

The 2 options can be used together, I think it is better to let developer choose.
Are you agree with that ?

items.title: Set_columns treats singleton and non_singleton column ranges differently
items.body:
Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to set the column width with set_column(), but it appears to have different behavior when calling singleton and non_singleton ranges.  In the code below, it can be seen that calling set_columns with singleton ranges is not overridden by subsequent calls using non-singleton  ranges.  However, calls to set_columns with non_singleton ranges are overridden by subsequent calls with either singleton or non-singleton ranges.  Additionally, calls to set_columns with singleton ranges are overridden by subsequent calls with singleton ranges.

This behavior occurs when using numeric or character column indexes.

The expected behavior is that set_columns treats singleton and non-singleton ranges in the same manner.  I prefer that both are overridden by subsequent calls to set_columns.

I am using Python version 3.8, XlsxWriter 1.27, and Excel version 2001 (Build 12430.20264)

Here is some code that demonstrates the issue:

```python
import pandas as pd
d = {'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': ['this is a very long cell that needs more width', 'not so big'],
     'col3': [3, 4], 'col4': [7, 8]}
col_width = [3, 50]
df = pd.DataFrame(data=d)
file_name = 'C:\\\test.xlsx'
with pd.ExcelWriter(file_name, engine='xlsxwriter') as writer:

    #   Test1
    #   The width of a range of columns is set twice
    #   The first call to set_columns is overridden by the second call to set_columns
    #   Columns 0-3 have width = col_width[1]
    #   Column 4 has the default width

    sheet_name = 'test1'
    df.to_excel(writer, sheet_name)
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column(0, 3, col_width[0])
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column(0, 3, col_width[1])

    #   Test2
    #   The width of the single column 2 is set PRIOR to setting a range of columns which includes the single column 2.
    #   The width of the single column 2 is NOT overridden by the second call to set_columns.
    #   Column 2 has width = col_width[1]
    #   Columns 0,1,and 3 have width = col_width[0]
    #   Column 4 has the default width

    sheet_name = 'test2'
    df.to_excel(writer, sheet_name)
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column(2, 2, col_width[1])
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column(0, 3, col_width[0])

    #   Test3
    #   The width of the single column 2 is set AFTER to setting a range of columns which includes the single column 2.
    #   The width of the single column overrides the first call to set_columns.
    #   Column 2 has width = col_width[1]
    #   Columns 0,1,and 3 have width = col_width[0]
    #   Column 4 has the default width

    sheet_name = 'test3'
    df.to_excel(writer, sheet_name)
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column(0, 3, col_width[0])
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column(2, 2, col_width[1])

    #   Test4
    #   The width of the single column 2 is set twice.
    #   The first call to set_columns is overridden by the second call to set_columns.
    #   Column 2 has width = col_width[0]
    #   Columns 0,1,3, and 4 have the default width

    sheet_name = 'test4'
    df.to_excel(writer, sheet_name)

    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column(2, 2, col_width[1])
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column(2, 2, col_width[0])

    #   Test1a- Test4a 
    #   Identical tests using character rather than numeric range references
    #   Identical behavior by set_columns is exhibited 
    
    sheet_name = 'test1a'
    df.to_excel(writer, sheet_name)
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column('A:D', col_width[0])
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column('A:D', col_width[1])

    sheet_name = 'test2a'
    df.to_excel(writer, sheet_name)
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column('C:C', col_width[1])
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column('A:D', col_width[0])

    sheet_name = 'test3a'
    df.to_excel(writer, sheet_name)
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column('A:D', col_width[0])
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column('C:C', col_width[1])

    sheet_name = 'test4a'
    df.to_excel(writer, sheet_name)
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column('C:C', col_width[1])
    writer.sheets[sheet_name].set_column('C:C', col_width[0])
```
[test.xlsx](https://github.com/jmcnamara/XlsxWriter/files/4221065/test.xlsx)

items.title: Column chart ignores fill color specification
items.body:
Relevant documentation:
https://xlsxwriter.readthedocs.io/working_with_charts.html#chart-formatting-fill

Note that I'm using the latest version on a reasonable Python:

```
X:\>        python -c "import xlsxwriter; print(xlsxwriter.__version__)"
1.2.7

X:\>        python --version
Python 3.7.4
```

Simple program to trigger the bug.

```
import xlsxwriter, os
filename = "bug.xlsx"
with xlsxwriter.Workbook(filename) as book:
	sheet = book.add_worksheet('bug')
	chart = book.add_chart({'type':'column'})
	
	COLOR = ['red', 'green', 'blue',]
	SAMPLE = [
		[1,2,3,4,5],
		[5,4,3,2,1],
		[4,1,5,3,2],
	]
	
	
	for row, (color, sample) in enumerate(zip(COLOR, SAMPLE)):
		fmt = book.add_format({'bg_color':color})
		sheet.write(row, 0, color, fmt)
		sheet.write_row(row, 1, sample, fmt)
		chart.add_series({
			'name': color,
			'values': ['bug', row, 1, row, len(sample)],
			'fill': {'color:': color},
		})
	
	sheet.merge_range(4,0,4,5, "The chart below gets the fill colors wrong!")
	sheet.insert_chart(5,0, chart)
os.startfile(filename)
```

I've not been able to figure out a work-around.
Line and marker color works fine.

items.body:
# Opening XlsxWriter Issues

## Asking questions about using XlsxWriter

General questions on how to do something with the XlsxWriter module should be
asked on [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/xlsxwriter).
Add the ``xlsxwriter`` tag to the question. This has a better chance of
getting several answers and also helps others who might have similar questions
in the future.


See below for information on adding a Bug Report or Feature Request.


## Reporting Bugs

Modify the following to suit.


Title: Issue with SOMETHING

Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to do SOMETHING but it appears to do SOMETHING ELSE.

I am using Python version X.Y.Z and XlsxWriter x.y.z and Excel version X.

Here is some code that demonstrates the problem:

```python

import pdb
import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('rich_strings_test.xlsx')
worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet()

left =  workbook.add_format({'align': 'left'})
right =  workbook.add_format({'align': 'right'})

worksheet.write_rich_string(0,0,left,'Left'," ABC ",right,'right')
workbook.close()

```

Notes:

1. Ensure that the example code can be run to generate a file that
   demonstrates the issue.
2. Only include code that relates to the issue.
3. Remove non-relevant text from this template.
4. If you are seeing an issue in LibreOffice, OpenOffice or another third
   party application, also test the output with a version of Excel.
5. You can get the required version numbers as follows:

        python --version
        python -c 'import xlsxwriter; print(xlsxwriter.__version__)'


## Feature requests

Add `Feature request:` to the title.

In the comment section describe the feature that you would like to be added.

If you are currently using a workaround you can show that workaround.

Docker container: python:3.6-slim
xlsxwriter version: 1.2.7
Python version: 3.6.8

I am attempting to write a Server side response to a POST call using xlsxwriter. I am able to make the call, and send the data stream to my client, but i am unable to decode it on the client side using javascript. items.title: Issue with escaping CR when opening xlsx file with LibreOffice Calc
items.body:
Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to do set a column heading that includes a line break.
e.g.
```
sheet.merge_range(r, 6, r, 7, "Department charges\r\n@ Department pricing")
```

I am running Linux and using LibreOffice Calc to open the file that is created.
I see `_x000D_` displayed in the cell for the CR from the \r
I understand that this is due to escaping the CR (in _write_si in [sharedstrings.py](https://github.com/jmcnamara/XlsxWriter/blob/master/xlsxwriter/sharedstrings.py))

If I open the xlsx file in Excel the cell displays as intended.
If I then save the file from Excel and open it in LibreOffice Calc then the cell displays as intended.

Comparing the file written by xlsxwriter and the file saved from Excel shows that **Excel does not escape the CR** but leaves it as the single byte with the value 0x0D

I understand that this may be a failing of LibreOffice Calc, but I believe that if xlsxwriter were modified to NOT escape CR then the result would be accepted by both LibreOffice Cal and Excel, and would agree with what Excel writes itself.

I am using Python version 2.7.15 and XlsxWriter 0.9.6 and LibreOffice Calc 6.0.7.3

Of course I should update xlsxwriter, but the escaping appears to be the same in the latest version.

Thank you for a very useful library!

items.title: Feature request: allow cell errors to be ignored
items.body:
I need to produce a spreadsheet where cells contain long numerical strings, representing object IDs.

If a value is added to the cell as an `int`, precision is lost and the value is shown with scientific notation.  Eg `12345678901234567890` is stored as `12345678901234500000` and is rendered as `1.23457E+19`.

If a value is added to the cell as a `str`, then we avoid the precision problems, but Excel displays a warning about a number being stored as text.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28734/71676729-e0427a80-2d78-11ea-86e1-1d33895637e8.png)

My current workaround is to hack `Worksheet._assemble_xml_file` so that it adds XML like the following:

```
  <ignoredErrors>
    <ignoredError sqref="A:A" numberStoredAsText="1"/>
    <ignoredError sqref="D:D" numberStoredAsText="1"/>
  </ignoredErrors>
```

items.title: Chart x_offset positioning not working when chart is put in a hidden column
items.body:
I've found a difference in how XlsxWriter behaves when inserting charts into hidden columns. In XlsxWriter version 1.1.5, the chart x_offsets are honoured, but starting in version 1.1.6 they aren't and the charts are drawn on top of each other if the column the charts is being inserted into is hidden.

I am using Python 2.7.11

Here is some code that demonstrates the problem:

```python

import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('chart.xlsx')
worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet()

# Write some data to add to plot on the chart.
data = [
    [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
    [2, 4, 6, 8, 10],
    [3, 6, 9, 12, 15],
]

worksheet.write_column('A1', data[0])
worksheet.write_column('B1', data[1])
worksheet.write_column('C1', data[2])

# Hide column A
worksheet.set_column(0, 0, 10, options={'hidden': True})

# Add a chart
chart = workbook.add_chart({'type': 'bar'})
chart.add_series({'values': '=Sheet1!$B$1:$B$5',
        'categories': '=Sheet1!$A1$1:$A:$5',
        'data_labels': {'value': True},
        'gap': 10})
chart.set_title({'name': 'Chart 1'})
chart.set_size({'width': 300})

# Insert the chart into the worksheet.
worksheet.insert_chart('A7', chart, {'x_offset': 20, 'y_offset': 5})

chart = workbook.add_chart({'type': 'bar'})
chart.add_series({'values': '=Sheet1!$C$1:$C$5',
        'categories': '=Sheet1!$A1$1:$A:$5',
        'data_labels': {'value': True},
        'gap': 10})
chart.set_title({'name': 'Chart 2'})
chart.set_size({'width': 300})
worksheet.insert_chart('A7', chart, {'x_offset': 400, 'y_offset': 5})

workbook.close()
```

Attached are the output files generated with XlsxWriter 1.1.5 and 1.1.6. The behaviour of 1.2.6 is the same as 1.1.6.
[chart-1.1.5.xlsx](https://github.com/jmcnamara/XlsxWriter/files/3879635/chart-1.1.5.xlsx)
[chart-1.1.6.xlsx](https://github.com/jmcnamara/XlsxWriter/files/3879637/chart-1.1.6.xlsx)

items.title: Issue with combine charts with secondary Y axis
items.body:
Hi,

I am trying to combine column and line charts both with secondary Y axis to create single combine chart with 2 Y axes. I have found that some combination of series with y2_axis leads to creation of multiple secondary Y axes, which causes wps-office to crash, and online excel marks it as broken and tried to repair it with message "Removed Part: /xl/drawings/drawing1.xml part.  (Drawing shape)". In libreoffice it works and the result is chart with 3 Y axes (one primary and two secondary axes). I've not found any mention of excel supporting multiple secondary axes and this does not look like an intended feature.
I've tried using Python version 2.7.16 with XlsxWriter 1.2.2 and Python 3.7.5 with XlsxWriter 1.2.2, same result for both Python versions.

Example code:

```python

import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('busted.xlsx')
chart_sheet = workbook.add_worksheet("chart")
data_sheet = workbook.add_worksheet("data")

data_sheet.write_column(0, 0, [1, 2, 3, 4])
data_sheet.write_column(0, 1, [2, 5, 8, 11])
data_sheet.write_column(0, 2, [40, 30, 20, 10])
data_sheet.write_column(0, 3, [10, 20, 30, 40])

column = workbook.add_chart({"type": "column"})
column.add_series({"values": ["data", 0, 0, 3, 0], "y2_axis": True})
column.add_series({"values": ["data", 0, 1, 3, 1]})

line = workbook.add_chart({"type": "line"})
line.add_series({"values": ["data", 0, 2, 3, 2]})
line.add_series({"values": ["data", 0, 3, 3, 3], "y2_axis": True})

column.combine(line)
chart_sheet.insert_chart(1, 0, column)
workbook.close()

```

Works fine if line chart uses only primary axis.
Overlapping columns for different Y axes is an excel limitation, not part of this issue.

Is there any way to assign series of different charts to use both Y axes?

items.title: Disable "strings to Formula" by default
items.body:
By default, XlsxWriter expands cells starting with `=` into formulas. Having this behavior happen by default is dangerous as it makes it easy to write code which is vulnerable to formula injections. Wouldn't it be safer to make this an opt-in instead?

See https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/29095

```python
import xlsxwriter
```

```python
if __name__ == '__main__': main()
```

Thanks!

```python
chart3.add_series({'values': '=Sheet1!$C$1:$C$5', 'y2_axis': True})

chart1.combine(chart3)
chart1.combine(chart2)
```


items.title: feature: set column width when add_table in a worksheet
items.body:
A user wants to set the width of a column at the time of the creation of a table.

Currently, a user supplies header this ways:

```
[{'header': 'Name'},
 {'header': 'Email'},
 {'header': 'Status'},
 {'header': 'Date Joined'},
 {'header': 'AWS Identifier'},
 {'header': 'AWS Resource Name'}]
```

Howeve, the user want to supply column width to such that the column with would be set when code executes `add_table`:

```
[{'header': 'Name', 'width': 100},
 {'header': 'Email', 'width': 100},
 {'header': 'Status', 'width': 100},
 {'header': 'Date Joined', 'width': 100},
 {'header': 'AWS Identifier', 'width': 100},
 {'header': 'AWS Resource Name', 'width': 100}]
```

In `xlsxwriter/worksheet.py`, there is a function `add_table`. The options allow for the supplying of `columns`.

```py
       # Valid input parameters.
        valid_parameter = {
            'columns': True,
```

The code check for user defined data:

```py
                if user_data:
                    # Get the column format.
                    xformat = user_data.get('format', None)

                    # Map user defined values to internal values.
                    if user_data.get('header'):
                        col_data['name'] = user_data['header']
```

Similar to how `name` is being set in `col_data`, we could set the width only once:

```py
                    # Excel requires unique case insensitive header names.
                    header_name = col_data['name']
                    name = header_name.lower()
                    if name in seen_names:
                        warn("Duplicate header name in add_table(): '%s'"
                             % force_unicode(name))
                        return -1
                    else:
                        # TODO: proposed change
                        if user_data.get('width'):
                            col_data['width'] = user_data['width']
                        # TODO: End of proposed change
                        seen_names[name] = True
```

Next, write after we write the `header_row`, we check whether `'width' in col_data` and if it is, then we set column width.

```py
            # Write the column headers to the worksheet.
            if options['header_row']:
                self._write_string(first_row, col_num, col_data['name'],
                                   col_data['name_format'])
                # TODO: proposed change
                if 'width' in col_data:
                    self.set_column(col_num, col_num, col_data['width'])
                # TODO: End of proposed change
```

Please provide feedback. If it looks good to you, then I will open a PR for this one.

items.title: Issue with Image Insertion on top of Hidden Columns
items.body:
Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to insert an image on top of columns that may or may not be hidden (this is at user discretion). When I insert an image on top of a hidden column then the image is re-sized. I do not want this to happen. I expected that using the 'object_position' argument and supplying option 3 ('don't move or size with cells') would solve the problem. But, in fact, it seems that none of the 'image_position' options resolve the behaviour.

I believe that this behaviour is different to the default behaviour of MS Excel, and accordingly I suspect that this is a bug. However, I am happy for someone to point out if i'm doing something incorrectly.

I am using Python version 3.7.0 and XlsxWriter 1.1.8 and Excel version 2016 MSO (16.0.4738.1000) 32-bit.

Here's a minimal illustration:

```python

import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('test.xlsx')
worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet()

worksheet.insert_image('A1', 'cat.jpg', {'object_position': 1})
worksheet.insert_image('A12', 'cat.jpg', {'object_position': 2})
worksheet.insert_image('A24', 'cat.jpg', {'object_position': 3})
worksheet.insert_image('A36', 'cat.jpg', {'object_position': 4})

worksheet.set_column('B:D', None, None, {'hidden': 1})

workbook.close()

```

This produces an excel in which ALL images are horizontally crushed:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25436580/60171131-e5d76a80-9801-11e9-9a7d-2c1a767dceb4.png)

However, if I select cell A1 and then manually insert the image via the excel GUI then all is well:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25436580/60171295-3bac1280-9802-11e9-8533-3c841f18c496.png)

I note that this problem is very similar to issue #618 - here though I actually want the 'unwanted' behaviour from #618. Looking at the associated [commit](https://github.com/jmcnamara/XlsxWriter/commit/60167ac050eb9c65afb2dbc7fec88d9b1faa6922) it looks like 'object_position' argument 1 is intended to preserve this behaviour, but this doesn't work for me - as shown above.

items.title: Feature request: add user defined types to write()
items.body:
The worksheet `write()` method maps common Python types to corresponding Excel types. It deliberately doesn't try to map unknown/unhandled types to Excel strings (for example) since the decision on the type mapping should be made by the end user.

This mapping can be done by remapping data types before calling `write()` but there are cases where it is cleaner to do it in `write()`.

This is available in the Perl version of this module in a method called [add_write_handler()](https://metacpan.org/pod/Excel::Writer::XLSX#add_write_handler(-$re,-$code_ref-)). The Perl version relies on regular expressions but an equivalent version in Python could use types. 

For example, currently if you write an unhandled data type you get an TypeError:

```python
import xlsxwriter
import uuid

# Set up the workbook as usual.
workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('user_type.xlsx')
worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet()

# Make the first column wider for clarity.
worksheet.set_column('A:A', 40)

# Create a UUID.
my_uuid = uuid.uuid3(uuid.NAMESPACE_DNS, 'python.org')

# Write the UUID.
worksheet.write('A1', my_uuid)

workbook.close()
```

Output:
```
$ python myuuid.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "myuuid0.py", line 15, in <module>
    worksheet.write('A1', my_uuid)
  File "/path/xlsxwriter/worksheet.py", line 69, in cell_wrapper
    return method(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/path/xlsxwriter/worksheet.py", line 413, in write
    return self._write(row, col, *args)
  File "/path/xlsxwriter/worksheet.py", line 493, in _write
    raise TypeError("Unsupported type %s in write()" % type(token))
TypeError: Unsupported type <class 'uuid.UUID'> in write()
```

With the proposed new API you could add a handler/callback for this, or other, types:

```python
import xlsxwriter
import uuid

# Create a function that will behave like a worksheet write() method. 
#
# This function takes a UUID and writes it as as string. It should take the
# parameters shown below and return the return value from the called worksheet
# write_*() method.
#
def write_uuid(worksheet, row, col, token, format=None):
    return worksheet.write_string(row, col, str(token), format)

# Set up the workbook as usual.
workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('user_type.xlsx')
worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet()

# Make the first column wider for clarity.
worksheet.set_column('A:A', 40)

# Add the write() handler/callback to the worksheet.
worksheet.add_write_handler(uuid.UUID, write_uuid)

# Create a UUID.
my_uuid = uuid.uuid3(uuid.NAMESPACE_DNS, 'python.org')

# Write the UUID.
worksheet.write('A1', my_uuid)

workbook.close()
```

Output:

![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94267/59162934-723f1900-8af1-11e9-8bb3-17e052f458e9.png)

items.title: Issue drawing the x type marker on  a line chart
items.body:
Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to do draw series on a line chart, but if I set the marker to be "x" it won't be set correctly (it will be set as a square).


I am using Python version 3.6.3 and XlsxWriter 1.1.8 and Excel version 2013.
It happens on Python version 3.6.5 and XlsxWriter 1.1.8 and Excel version 2019 too.

Here is some (minimal) code that demonstrates the problem:

```python

import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook('test_x_marker.xlsx')

data = [10, 40, 50, 20, 10, 50]

chart.add_series({'values': '=Sheet1!$A$1:$A$6',
                  'line': {'color': '#7D60A0'},
                  'marker': {'type': 'x', 'size': 7, 'fill': {'color': '#7D60A0'}, 'border': {'color': '#7D60A0'}}})

worksheet.insert_chart('C1', chart)
workbook.close()

```

(I can display square, triangle, diamond and circle markers just fine)

My code originally  wrotes 4 series and I used 'marker': 'automatic': in this case the 4th serie would display a X as the marker.
When I switched to customizable series format I found out that I couldn't draw the X marker. 

Opening the chart1.xml file (contaied into the xlsx file) I noticed there's e <c:marker val="1"/>, which I suppose should be <c:marker val="4"/> instead (x is the 4th type of marker, square is the 1st).

items.title: Feature request: Tables in constant memory mode
items.body:
Hi! I realize it's explicitly mentioned in the documentation, but I'm wondering: is it at all possible to allow adding tables in constant memory mode? I first tried OpenPyXL, which supposedly can do this, but it seems broken. (While the code outputs no errors, the file appears corrupted to Excel.) I was hopeful to find a solution with this package, but that got thrown out the window... (Though I might prefer this package anyways.) No other package seems to have the functionality, either.

If it's not feasible/possible, could you mention the reason for it? Is it some underlying XML structure thing?

Thanks for your time.

items.title: Issue with retrieving data from a different sheet when reference encapsulated in function
items.body:
Title: Issue with retrieving data from a different sheet when reference encapsulated in function

Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to tally up totals from one sheet with data from another, using standard formulas and Excel spreadsheet syntax. It doesn't cause errors in python, but when I open the sheet in Excel, it reports the sheet is corrupted.:
"We found a problem with some content in 'xsrbug.xlsx'. Do you want us to recover as much as we can? If you trust the source of this workbook, click Yes."

If I choose No, the workbook isn't opened. If I choose yes, the cross-sheet formulas are set to integer 0. I guess that part is as designed, of course...

Manually adding the formula to the sheet and saving it, works fine.

I am using Python version 3.7.2 and XlsxWriter 1.1.8 and Excel Office 365.

Here is some code that demonstrates the problem:

```
#!/usr/bin/python3

# Cross sheet reference bug

import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook("xsrbug.xlsx")

t_data =	[	["Issue:", "Arg1", "Arg2"],
				["issue 1", 1, 2 ],
				["issue 2", 3, 4 ],
				["issue 3", 5, 6 ]
			]

ws_stats = workbook.add_worksheet("Statistics")
ws_data = workbook.add_worksheet("Data")

# Write table t_data to data sheet
for r_data_enum, r_data in enumerate(t_data):
	for c_data_enum, c_data in enumerate(r_data):
		ws_data.write(r_data_enum, c_data_enum, c_data)

# Write statistics to statistics sheet

ws_stats.write("A1", "Name")
ws_stats.write("B1", "Expected value")
ws_stats.write("C1", "Formula that should calculate")
ws_stats.write("D1", "Add an '=' in front for proof that the formula should work")

ws_stats.write("A2", "Number of issues")
ws_stats.write("B2", len(t_data)-1)
ws_stats.write("C2", "=COUNTIF(Data!A:A;\"*\")-1") # This corrupts
ws_stats.write("D2", "COUNTIF(Data!A:A;\"*\")-1")

ws_stats.write("A3", "Value of Data!B4")
ws_stats.write("B3", 5)
ws_stats.write("C3", "=Data!B4") # This works just fine
ws_stats.write("D3", "Data!B4")
workbook.close()

```

items.title: Possible to store Numbers as Text without the excel warning?
items.body:
I'm writing numbers intentionally as text to a worksheet. Is there a format I can set to get Excel to not report "Numbers stored as text"? Excel isn't smart enough to detect what I want.

Examples:
   `100`      (warning)
   `100, 200`   (no warning due to the non-numeric characters)

I've tried `num_format=@`, but it still complains. If there's no solution, I guess I could iterate back over my table and set the formats for the single numbers to a number.

items.title: Issue with set_column actual width different from set width
items.body:
Hi,

I am using XlsxWriter to do set the width to 8.5 but it appears to set it to 8.57. Setting 8.5x also sets it to 8.57.

I am using Python version 3.7 and XlsxWriter 1.1.6 and Excel version 2013.

Here is some code that demonstrates the problem:

```python
import xlsxwriter

workbook = xlsxwriter.Workbook("x.xlsx")
worksheet = workbook.add_worksheet()
worksheet.set_column('A:AF', 8.50)

workbook.close()
```
